item.title: Gracias a Bad Bunny, ahora todos conocen el coquito puertorriqueño
item.description: Esta bebida de ron y coco solía compartirse entre las familias puertorriqueñas, pero ahora que existe un mayor interés por la cultura de la isla su popularidad ha aumentado.
item.dc:creator: Taylor Robinson and Natalie Keyssar

media:content.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times

item.title: Kennedy Center Chief Threatens Legal Action Over Canceled Christmas Concert
item.description: The musician Chuck Redd called off the annual Christmas Eve performances after the Kennedy Center board added President Trump’s name to the performing arts center.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Crews added President Trump’s name to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Dec. 19.

item.title: Before This Physicist Studied the Stars, He Was One
item.description: Brian Cox once toured as a keyboardist in major rock and pop bands. Now he’s a particle physicist on a new world tour with a dazzling show he designed in an era of science disinformation and denial.
item.dc:creator: Stefano Montali

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Professor Brian Cox backstage before a show. He is renowned for his adroitness in explaining the intricacies and magnificence of space.

item.title: Corrections: December 27, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, December 27, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: It Was Lighter Than a Token. Now It’s Litter.
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 27, 2025.

item.title: Karoline Leavitt Says She’s Expecting Her Second Child
item.description: The White House press secretary announced on Instagram that she was pregnant with a daughter who is due in May. She and her husband have a 1-year-old son.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, this month at the office. She’s the youngest person to hold the job.

item.title: Thailand and Cambodia Reach Cease-Fire in Brutal Border War
item.description: The 72-hour cease-fire could pave the way for an end to the fighting, which has killed dozens and displaced thousands over nearly three weeks.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

media:content.media:credit: Agence Kampuchea Presse, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A photo released by Cambodia’s state news agency showed Cambodia’s defense minister, Tea Seiha, left, and his Thai counterpart, Nattaphon Narkphanit, posing with documents at a border checkpoint in Thailand’s Chanthaburi Province, after their two countries agreed to a cease-fire on Saturday.

item.title: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘What We Can Know’
item.description: Ian McEwan’s latest novel, one of the Book Review’s 100 Notable Books of 2025, is a literary mystery about a scholar’s search for a long-lost poem.

media:content.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Penguin Random House

item.title: What Many Wine Corks Do
item.description: Katie Hoody sweeps up solvers in a buoyant themeless puzzle
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Water skiers taking the leap.

item.title: Jury Declines Murder Charge Against Parent in Kentucky State Shooting
item.description: The grand jury received testimony that the man had acted to defend his son, who had faced bullying before the shooting, a local prosecutor said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:credit: Hannah Brown/The State Journal, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Law enforcement officers responded to a shooting at Kentucky State University’s campus in Frankfort, Ky., this month.

item.title: Why We Are Going to the Fastest-Melting Glacier
item.description: How much time does the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica have left? Our reporter Raymond Zhong and our photographer Chang W. Lee are joining scientists and engineers who measure how much sea levels could rise as a result of melting ice.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Thomas Vollkommer, Leila Medina and Stephanie Swart

item.title: Driver Livestreaming on TikTok Is Charged After Fatally Striking Pedestrian, Police Say
item.description: The driver, who is known to her followers as Tea Tyme, was charged with two felonies in connection with the crash last month, the police in Illinois said.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

item.title: Police Respond to Report of a Shooting at an Idaho Sheriff’s Office
item.description: The shooting happened at the Shoshone County Sheriff’s Office in Wallace, Idaho, on Friday. The gunman was killed by the police, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler and Mark Walker

item.title: What Went Wrong Before Hong Kong’s Inferno
item.description: Records show how government departments played down residents’ warnings about corrupt practices and substandard materials that fueled the deadly blaze.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan and Joy Dong
item.category: Prestige Construction and Engineering Co Ltd

media:content.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Wang Fuk Court apartment complex in Hong Kong days after a fire on Nov. 26 killed 161 people and displaced thousands.

item.title: Trump dice que los ataques en Nigeria fueron contra el Estado Islámico
item.description: Aunque las autoridades nigerianas han rebatido las afirmaciones de Trump sobre un “genocidio” cristiano, han optado por responder a sus amenazas cooperando con su gobierno.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Saikou Jammeh and Ismail Auwal
item.category: US Strikes on ISIS in Nigeria (2025- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente Trump en Mar-a-Lago en Palm Beach, Florida, el lunes. Dijo que los objetivos del ataque del jueves contra el estado nigeriano de Sokoto eran miembros del Estado Islámico.

item.title: Annette Dionne, Last of the Celebrated Quintuplets, Dies at 91
item.description: She was the first to crawl, the first to cut a tooth, the first to recognize her name, and the last to die. And, like her sisters, she resented being exploited as part of a global sensation.
item.dc:creator: Jane Gross

media:content.media:credit: CP, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Clockwise from top left, Marie, Emelie, Annette, Yvonne and Cécile in 1952.

item.title: Perry Bamonte, Guitarist and Keyboardist in the Cure, Dies at 65
item.description: A former roadie, Mr. Bamonte joined the band in 1990. He played on five albums and in hundreds of shows and was “a vital part of the Cure story,” the band said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: Tim Mosenfelder/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Perry Bamonte of the Cure performing at the Shoreline Amphitheatre in 2000 in Mountain View, Calif.

item.title: Some G.O.P. Senators Join Democrats in Urging Trump to Adopt Hard Line With Putin
item.description: The president is planning to meet with the leader of Ukraine in Florida just as the lawmakers are applying some pressure.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk

item.title: A Wealth Tax Floated in California Has Billionaires Thinking of Leaving
item.description: It’s uncertain whether the proposal will reach the statewide ballot in November, but some billionaires like Peter Thiel and Larry Page may be unwilling to take the risk.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Theodore Schleifer and Heather Knight

media:content.media:credit: Marco Bello/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Peter Thiel, a tech venture capitalist, could face a tax bill of more than $1.2 billion if the proposed wealth tax is placed on the California ballot and approved by voters.

item.title: The Evolution of the Women in ‘The Great Gatsby’
item.description: In the final week of the 100th anniversary of “The Great Gatsby,” Wesley Morris, the host of ‘Cannonball,’ talks to the novelist Min Jin Lee and Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, about why all three of them have found themselves in a decades-long relationship with this book.
item.dc:creator: Cannonball With Wesley Morris

item.title: How ‘The Great Gatsby’ Captures the American Dream
item.description: In the final week of the 100th anniversary of “The Great Gatsby,” Wesley Morris, the host of ‘Cannonball,’ talks to the novelist Min Jin Lee and Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, about why all three of them have found themselves in a decades-long relationship with this book.

item.title: Israel Recognizes Somaliland, Drawing International Rebukes
item.description: The development carries potential benefits for both sides but still faces stiff international opposition, 34 years after the region broke away from Somalia.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Richard Pérez-Peña

media:content.media:description: A downed Somali Air Force MiG 17 on display at the Hargeisa War Memorial in Somaliland.

item.title: Trump Invited White South Africans to America. One Ended Up in Detention.
item.description: An Afrikaner flew to the United States expecting protection. Instead, he has spent months locked up in Georgia alongside hundreds of other immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan

media:content.media:credit: Mike Stewart/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A detention center in Lumpkin, Ga., where Benjamin Schoonwinkel, an Afrikaner, is being held.

item.title: The Break-Up: Inside the Unraveling U.S.-Ukraine Partnership
item.description: As President Trump sought a peace deal, factions in the White House and Pentagon starved the war effort and played into Russia’s hands.

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mr. Trump and Mr. Zelensky at the White House in August.

item.title: Snow Begins Falling in New York City, Threatening Havoc
item.description: Flights were canceled and streets grew slippery as the metropolitan region braced for heavy snow.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey

item.title: Zelenski dice que se reunirá con Trump el fin de semana
item.description: La reunión sería probablemente este domingo en Florida, según el presidente ucraniano Volodímir Zelenski. La Casa Blanca no ha dado una confirmación inmediata sobre la reunión.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

media:content.media:credit: Tetiana Dzhafarova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: El presidente de Ucrania, Volodímir Zelenski, ha reconocido importantes puntos de fricción en las conversaciones sobre un plan de paz para Ucrania.

item.description: On March 7, 2025, Said Murtazaliyev, an 18-year-old Russian soldier, sent his mother a video detailing bribes he said were paid to a commander and his deployment on a sure-death mission. After he disappeared, his mother used the footage to report that he was missing.

Social media footage that circulated in October shows two Russian soldiers tied to trees, allegedly as punishment by commanders. A different video of the same scene was used in an official complaint. The original footage has been cropped, and the audio removed, to protect the soldiers’ identities.

A video taken by a Russian soldier shows injured men, including Andrei Zubaryov, 31, apparently being sent on a combat mission. Mr. Zubaryov’s wife identified him in the footage as the man seen limping with a cane. Expletives have been removed from the audio.

item.title: Should Colleges End Early Decision?
item.description: Readers respond to a guest essay arguing that it is an unfair “racket. Also: An attack on climate research and safety; the value of immigrants to America.

media:content.media:credit: Jasmine Clarke for The New York Times

item.title: Michal Urbaniak, Pioneering Jazz Fusion Violinist, Dies at 82
item.description: One of the first jazz musicians from Poland to gain an international following, he recorded more than 60 albums and played with stars like Miles Davis.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:credit: Columbia Records
media:content.media:description: “Fusion” (1974), Mr. Urbaniak’s first major solo album, was an “enigmatic recording at once lyrical and noisy,” one reviewer wrote.

item.title: Esta puede ser la última oportunidad de EE. UU. de tener un buen resultado en Venezuela
item.description: Maduro está más aislado que nunca. Pero es poco probable que las demostraciones de fuerza por sí solas lo convenzan del inevitable fin de su régimen ilegítimo.

item.title: Why Sears’s Last Great Hope Was a Promise That Never Materialized
item.description: Only five Sears stores remain in the country, with the end likely near for what was once the mightiest American retailer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Coleman-Lochner

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The hedge fund magnate Edward Lampert’s plan to turn Sears stores into dazzling mixed-use developments had attracted prominent investors.

item.title: Trump’s Claims About Nigeria Strike Belie a Complex Situation on the Ground
item.description: President Trump said the targets of airstrikes in Nigeria were Islamic State terrorists responsible for killing Christians, but experts question his framing.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Saikou Jammeh, Ismail Auwal and Eric Schmitt
item.category: US Strikes on ISIS in Nigeria (2025- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on Monday. He said that the targets of Thursday’s strike on Sokoto State in Nigeria were members of the Islamic State.

item.title: Ham and Bean Soup Recipe for Leftover Holiday Ham

item.title: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of CVS Worker on Long Island
item.description: A resident of Lindenhurst was charged with the murder of a 23-year-old employee inside a CVS on Christmas Day, the authorities said.

item.title: Looking Back at Nancy Pelosi’s Career, Through The Times

item.title: New Jail Term for Ex-Malaysian Leader Najib Razak in Corruption Scandal

item.title: Downpours Ease in Southern California, but Flood Risks Remain
item.description: Another wave of rain was hitting the Los Angeles area on Friday, adding to the record-setting precipitation over Christmas.

media:content.media:description: Clouds covered downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday. Rain continued on Thursday and Friday.

item.title: A College Freshman Is the Unlikely Source of Alabama’s New Political Maps
item.description: Daniel DiDonato, 19, has loved elections since he was in fourth grade. He also loves maps.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina

media:content.media:credit: Mike Stewart/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A college freshman drew the maps to determine who will represent State Senate Districts 25 and 26 at the Alabama State Capitol.
